FacilityStr1: 7.16 miles west of Twin Buttes, ND

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Program 1 Risk Management Plan
Howling Wolf Production Pad
WPX Energy Williston, LLC

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

A leasing company operates a J-T plant designed to recover propane, butane and natural gasoline from gas prior to gathering and final treatment for WPX Energy, Inc. (WPX) at the Howling Wolf Production Pad.  This report provides the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the recovery skid system, pursuant to the requirements of the U.S. EPA RMP rule.

The system is designed to remove liquids from gas at the wellhead, having an inlet pressure between 150 and 400 psi.  The J-T valve system can generate temperatures as low as -20°F.  The leasing company uses this system to remove liquids from flared gases.  The portability of the unit allows it to easily be moved from site to site when flaring ceases.  The NGL storage tanks have an 18,000 gallon capacity. The leasing company will have four tanks onsite and the maximum fill for each tank is 14,400 gallons. The 57,600 gallons is equivalent to 328,896 lbs. of flammable liquids.

Under the authority of section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act, the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions require facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute, or store certain chemicals to develop a Risk Management Program, prepare a Risk Management Plan (RMP), and submit the RMP to EPA. Covered facilities were initially required to comply with the rule in 1999, and the rule has been amended on several occasions since then, most recently in 2004. This facility is regulated under Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68), more commonly known as the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule. RMP plans must be prepared for processes that store in excess of the thresholds set forth by 40 CFR 68.130. For flammable liquids, the threshold is 10,000 lbs.  This site can store approximately 328,896 lbs. of NGL and exceeds 10,000 lbs. threshold, thus the facility is subject to the requirements of the Chemical Accident Prevention r

ule and must prepare an RMP.
LOCATION

The Howling Wolf Production Pad is located in the NW ¼ of the SE ¼ of Section 21, Township 147N, Range 92W, Dunn County, North Dakota, on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation (FBIR).

Latitude: 47.537008, Longitude: -102.404483

DRIVING DIRECTIONS

From the intersection of BIA Route 22 & 80th Ave NW in Twin Buttes, ND, travel westerly on BIA Route 22 for 0.78 miles to fork in roadway. Keep Right (westerly) for 6.1 miles to fork in roadway; Go Left (North Westerly) for 1.9 miles to proposed access road. Go Right (Northerly) on proposed access road for 0.2 miles to staked Howling Wolf Production Pad location.   

DISPERSION MODELING ANALYSIS WITH RMP*COMP

RMP*Comp: Results of Consequence Analysis
Scenario Summary
October 10, 2018

Chemical Name           	CAS Number	Quantity Released (pounds)
Butane	                        106-97-8	75863
Ethane	                         74-84-0	22082
Isobutane [Propane, 2-methyl]	 75-28-5	23309
Isopentane [Butane, 2-methyl-]	 78-78-4	19592
Methane	                         74-82-8	451
Pentane	                        109-66-0	40477
Propane	                         74-98-6	147122

Threat type:      Flammable

Scenario type:  Worst-case

Release type:   Vapor Cloud Explosion
Estimated distance to 1 psi overpressure: 0.6 miles (0.9 kilometers)

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS: POPULATION AND ENVIRONMENT

After the distance to the flammable endpoint has been determined, the offsite impacts on population, public receptors, and environmental receptors should be analyzed as required by the RMP rule. The population within a circle centered at the point of release and a radius equal to the distance to the flammable endpoint should be estimated to two significant digits. In addition, all types of public receptors (schools, residences, hospitals, prisons, public recreation areas or arenas, major commercial or industrial areas) and environmental receptors (national or stat

e parks, forests, or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; federal wilderness areas) within this distance should be identified.

A field survey was used to estimate the potentially affected population within the distance to the flammable endpoint and to identify public receptors.  The survey showed that no population is within the 0.6 mile impact radius for the worst case release. The impact area on a map is demonstrated in appendix A. The types of public receptors and environmental receptors identified within the impact area are listed in Table 2-2.  Google Earth was used to find the public receptors within the impact radius. Additionally, no environmental receptors are impacted by the worst-case release scenario.
